channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: He Disavowed Radical Islam. Was He Lying?
item.media:description: French police officers, conducting a raid near Strasbourg in 2014, detained a man suspected of receiving jihadist training in Syria.
item.description: The case of seven men who went to Syria and returned home reflects a quandary for France and the rest of the Continent after the attacks in Paris and Brussels.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Britain’s Labour Party Leader Suspends Lawmaker Over Anti-Israel Posts
item.description: Naseem Shah was suspended by Jeremy Corbyn for endorsing anti-Israel posts on social media before she became a member of the British Parliament.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Doel Journal: Last Holdouts Struggle to Stop the Destruction of a Belgian Village
item.media:description: A group of holdouts in Doel, Belgium, is fighting a plan to level the town to make way for an expansion of the Port of Antwerp.
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.description: Just a handful of residents remain in Doel, which is set to be leveled to make way for an expansion of the Port of Antwerp.
item.dc:creator: NINA SIEGAL

item.title: Afghan Women, Eager to Play, Are Relegated to the Sidelines
item.media:description: Members of Afghanistan’s women’s national cycling team returning from training on the outskirts of Kabul in early April.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: With few exceptions, team sports programs for women are riddled with corruption and undermined by conservative Afghans who never liked the idea.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: U.S. Soldiers Defy North Korean Propaganda by Teaching Defectors English
item.media:description: Col. Maria Eoff, commander of the Yongsan United States Army Garrison in central Seoul, the main American military base in the capital, with a South Korean instructor, second from right, and students from the North at an English class last month.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: Much of the government propaganda in North Korea is intended to stoke fear and hatred of the United States — especially its service members.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Sinosphere: Book Debate Raises Questions of Self-Censorship by Foreign Groups in China
item.media:description: Teng Biao in 2013.
item.description: The dispute stems from a rejection by the American Bar Association of a potentially incendiary book being written by a Chinese human rights lawyer.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Egyptian Migrants Killed in Clash With Libyan Smugglers: Official
item.description: At least nine Egyptian migrants and three people smugglers were killed in a money dispute in the town of Bani Walid, a local official said on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: In Israel, Iraqi Jews Reflect on Baghdad Heritage
item.media:description: The reconstructed alleys of the Jewish quarter of Baghdad at the Babylonian Jewry Heritage Center in Or Yehuda, Israel, outside Tel Aviv.
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.description: As the number of Jews in Iraq has dwindled to nearly none, Iraqi Jews in Israel are taking fresh interest in a heritage once considered unseemly.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ and IRIT PAZNER GARSHOWITZ

item.title: 5 Rescue Workers Are Killed in Northern Syria
item.media:description: A civil defense station in Atareb, in western Aleppo Province in Syria, on Tuesday, after aerial attacks hit the headquarters.
item.description: Five rescue workers with a civil defense group were killed in aerial attacks on their headquarters in northern Syria on Tuesday as violence escalated in Aleppo Province.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: White Helmets (Syrian Civil Defense Volunteer Group)

item.title: A Former Girl Soldier in Colombia Finds ‘Life Is Hard’ as a Civilian
item.media:description: Fabio, 19, and Dora, 64, who rents a room to him in Caldas, Colombia. She worked in the kitchen of the center for demobilized children where Fabio was sent, and lost her son, Hector, to FARC sniper fire.
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.description: Charting a future for thousands of young rebel fighters like Mélida is vital to the success of any deal to end 50 years of armed conflict, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Protests as Venezuela Embraces 2-Day Workweek to Save Power
item.description: Venezuelan cities cleaned up from a night of looting and fiery protests as government offices closed their doors in the face of a worsening energy crisis that is causing daily blackouts.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Venezuela Panel Clears the Way for a Process to Oust Nicolás Maduro
item.media:description: Signatures being collected in Caracas, Venezuela, in support of President Nicolás Maduro’s removal from office. The country is now the second in the region undergoing an effort to remove its leader.
item.description: A decision by the country’s electoral commission lifted hopes of the opposition politicians, who have vowed to remove the president by the end of the year.
item.dc:creator: PATRICIA TORRES and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Riek Machar, South Sudan Opposition Leader, Returns as Part of Peace Deal
item.media:description: President Salva Kiir of South Sudan, right, with the opposition leader, Riek Machar, left, as Mr. Machar was sworn in as vice president on Tuesday in Juba, the capital.
item.description: Mr. Machar emerged from exile to be restored as vice president, but serious questions remained for a country ravaged by more than two years of civil war.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Press Freedom Weakened Around the World in 2015, Report Says
item.description: A report by Freedom House added to evidence showing that assaults on members of the news media are spreading beyond chronically dangerous areas.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Tibetans in Exile Re-elect Political Leader
item.description: The leader, Lobsang Sangay, 48, said he would push for talks with China to secure Tibet’s future and that of exiled Tibetans around the world.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND and TENZIN TSERING

item.title: Suicide Bombing Near Historic Mosque in Turkey Wounds 13
item.description: A female suicide bomber blew herself up near the Ulu Camii, or Grand Mosque, a popular tourist destination in a historic district of Bursa in northwestern Turkey.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Apple iPhone, Once a Status Symbol in China, Loses Its Luster
item.media:description: An Apple store in Beijing. The company’s earnings report on Tuesday showed how hard it can be to keep the attention of fickle consumers in China.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: The company’s second-quarter earnings show how hard it can be to keep the attention of the country’s fickle and increasingly hard-to-impress consumers.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: U.S. Ruling Over Compensation for ’83 Beirut Bombing Riles Iran
item.description: President Hassan Rouhani lashed out against the U.S. government after the decision, which allows the relatives of victims to sue Tehran for $2 billion in compensation.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Sinosphere: A Robot Monk Captivates China, Mixing Spirituality With Artificial Intelligence
item.description: The two-foot-tall robot Xian’er dwells in a Buddhist temple, dispensing wisdom about religion and life.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Big Ben to Fall Silent During Renovation
item.media:description: Big Ben in London on Tuesday. The clock and tower will undergo a three-year, $42 million refurbishment.
item.description: The famed clock tower’s bells at the Houses of Parliament in London will not toll for a while, but when isn’t clear. The clock will keep ticking, most of the time.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Kept From Australia, Refugee at Nauru Center Sets Himself on Fire
item.description: The Iranian asylum seeker set himself on fire during a visit by United Nations officials to the detention center on the Pacific island nation of Nauru.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Salah Abdeslam, Suspect in Paris Attacks, Is Extradited to France
item.media:description: Salah Abdeslam
item.media:credit: French Police, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Salah Abdeslam, who is also believed to be connected to the attacks in Brussels, was handed over by Belgium and charged, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Ilham Tohti, Uighur Scholar Jailed in China, Is Nominated for Rights Award
item.media:description: Ilham Tohti, a scholar and advocate for China’s Uighur ethnic minority, at home in Beijing in February 2013.
item.description: The nomination of Mr. Tohti, selected for trying to promote dialogue in the troubled Xinjiang region of China, was all but certain to anger Beijing.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: North Korea to Convene Rare Party Congress Next Week
item.media:description: A monument to the founding of the Workers’ Party in Pyongyang, the capital of North Korea.
item.description: The congress, the first since 1980, is a likely platform for the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un, to cement his authority.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Israel’s Vow to Keep Golan Brings ‘Deep Concern’ at Security Council
item.media:description: Soldiers from Israel last month during military exercises in the Israeli-annexed Golan Heights, near the border with Syria.
item.description: The Security Council president said Resolution 497, which described Israel’s annexation of the Golan Heights as ‘null and void,’ remains in effect.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Spain to Hold New Elections After Coalition Talks Fail
item.description: The nation has been politically paralyzed since an election on Dec. 20, when voters ended the country’s traditional two-party system.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: After Missteps, U.S. Tightens Rules for Espionage Cases
item.media:description: The Justice Department last year dropped all charges against Xiaoxing Xi, head of Temple University’s physics department; he had been accused of sharing sensitive American-made technology with China.
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.description: Prosecutors in Washington will have greater oversight after the collapse of several cases led to allegations that Chinese-Americans were being singled out as spies.
item.dc:creator: MATT APUZZO

item.title: Cardinal and Longtime Catholic Leader in Cuba to Step Down
item.description: Jaime Ortega y Alamino has been a savvy political operator who aided the Vatican’s secret efforts to broker détente between Washington and Havana.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT
item.category: Garcia Rodriguez, Juan de la Caridad

item.title: VW Presentation in ’06 Showed How to Foil Emissions Tests
item.media:description: The Volkswagen logo on a Nasdaq screen. Admissions of cheating on emissions tests have weighed on the company’s stock.
item.description: The proposal, discovered as part of the investigations into Volkswagen, provides a direct link to the genesis of the diesel deception.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Church of England Calls on God to Help ‘Brexit’ Voters
item.media:description: The archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, said last month that the Church of England would stay neutral on the debate over whether Britain should remain in the European Union.
item.description: A prayer that asks that voters be imbued with “discernment” was seen by some as a sign that the church sides with those who want Britain to stay in the European Union.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Tatar Legislature Is Banned in Crimea
item.description: Tatars, who were the lone voice of opposition to Russia’s annexation of Crimea, have often been subject to harassment there.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Trilobites: Now Is the Time to See Squid That Glow Like Fireflies
item.media:description: A firefly squid in Japan. The best time to see them is between March and June.
item.media:credit: Michael Ready/Visuals Unlimited, Inc., via Getty Images
item.description: Each year, between March and June, millions of firefly squid transform a Japanese bay’s waters into a galactic landscape.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN

item.title: Trilobites: 30 Years After Chernobyl Disaster, Shelter Nears Completion
item.media:description: Inside and out, the arch is covered in stainless steel, and dehumidified air will be circulated around the structure’s steel trusses to prevent rust.
item.media:credit: European Bank for Reconstructino and Development
item.description: The arch has been built to last 100 years without the sort of maintenance that most structures require.
item.dc:creator: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Iranian Court Sentences 4 Journalists to Long Prison Terms
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran in Istanbul, in April. The imprisoned journalists were his supporters.
item.description: The four were arrested last November in a crackdown by the hard-line judiciary, and the convictions were seen as a warning to all Iranian journalists.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Justin Trudeau, Politician and Star of His Own Viral Universe
item.media:description: Justin Trudeau, the prime minister of Canada, with the panda cubs Jia Panpan and Jia Yueyue at the Toronto Zoo last month, in an image from his Twitter account.
item.media:credit: Office of the Canadian Prime Minister, via Twitter
item.description: Mr. Trudeau has become a digital star many times over since his election as Canada’s prime minister in October. (Roll the video on quantum computing.)
item.dc:creator: JONAH BROMWICH

item.title: India-Pakistan Meeting Raises Hopes for Improved Relations
item.media:description: Foreign Secretary Aizaz Ahmad Chaudhry of Pakistan after a meeting with his Indian counterpart on Tuesday in New Delhi.
item.description: The foreign secretaries of India and Pakistan held a brief bilateral meeting on the sidelines of a regional gathering.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR and GEETA ANAND

item.title: Indonesia Moves to Investigate Anti-Communist Atrocities
item.media:description: Maj. Gen. Suharto, holding stick at front left, in 1965. General Suharto helped crush the Communist movement in Indonesia and went on to rule the country from 1967 to 1998.
item.description: It was a sign that the government might end its official reluctance to confront the 1965-66 purges, in which hundreds of thousands may have been killed.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY HUTTON
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: With Putin Looking On, Russian Rocket Fails to Launch
item.description: Russia’s space agency postponed the inaugural launch of a rocket from the Vostochny Cosmodrome in the Far East, citing technical problems.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA ODYNOVA

item.title: Sinosphere: ‘Doctor Strange’ Writer Explains Casting of Tilda Swinton as Tibetan
item.media:description: Tilda Swinton, at the Berlin International Film Festival on Feb. 11. Some have questioned her casting as the Ancient One in “Doctor Strange.”
item.description: C. Robert Cargill said the filmmakers wanted to avoid the character’s origins, in large part over fears of offending China and of losing access to its lucrative market.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Rome Journal: A Roman Legion of Volunteers Retakes the Tiber
item.media:description: A section of Tiberina Island in Rome, the only island in the Tiber River. The river’s filthy waterfront and murky waters are a painful reflection of the widespread neglect and degeneration that has blemished Rome’s beauty.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: Citizens frustrated with the government have banded together to clean up the riverfront, part of a surge in grass-roots efforts to restore Rome’s public spaces.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: A Burst of Energy in Bangladesh
item.description: The government has made great strides in increasing energy capacity. But it needs to give power to the people, too.
item.dc:creator: TAHMIMA ANAM
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Obama’s Last Chance to End the ‘Forever War’
item.media:credit: Illustration by Adam Maida; Photo by Zach Gibson/The New York Times
item.description: The Obama administration has been fighting a semi-legal war for almost eight years. That’s not a power he should leave for the next president.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER DASKAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Out of Africa, Part III
item.media:description: Matador
item.description: In Senegal, a rap artist and a weatherman both worry for their nation’s future.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
